head.title: When the Choice Is Suffering or Death

hedline.hl1: When the Choice Is Suffering or Death

abstract.p: Prof Timothy E Quill letter on June 20 article cites benefits of legalizing physician-assisted suicide

block.p: Your June 20 front-page article about the Netherlands' quest to legalize euthanasia conflates the practices of physician-assisted suicide, voluntary active euthanasia and ''mercy killing.''
Your June 20 front-page article about the Netherlands' quest to legalize euthanasia conflates the practices of physician-assisted suicide, voluntary active euthanasia and ''mercy killing.''

In physician-assisted suicide, competent terminally ill patients experiencing unrelievable suffering obtain prescriptions for and self-administer potentially lethal medication. This practice is not ''voluntary active euthanasia,'' in which doctors administer lethal drugs at the patient's request, or ''mercy killing,'' in which the patient may or may not have initiated the procedure.

For many years, the Netherlands openly tolerated the two former methods but kept them technically illegal. In Oregon, since physician-assisted suicide was legalized, there have been very few such cases, and simultaneously hospice referrals have increased, pain management has improved, and more patients die at home. If these are the effects of legalization, other states should consider adopting this approach.
TIMOTHY E. QUILL, M.D. Rochester, June 23, 2000
The writer is a professor of medicine and psychiatry at the University of Rochester School of Medicine.
